description: From Middle English belchen, from Old English bielċan, from Proto-Germanic *balkijaną, *belkaną, probably ultimately of imitative origin.
Related to Dutch balken (“to bray”), Middle Low German belken (“to shout”), Low German bölken (“to shout, bark”), Old English bealċettan (“to utter, send forth”). See also English bolk, boak.

entries.meaning: The sound one makes when belching.

examples: Porters would no longer be drunk with Belch

verbs.description: belch (third-person singular simple present belches, present participle belching, simple past and past participle belched)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To expel (gas) loudly from the stomach through the mouth.
examples: When I an amorous kiss design'd,
I belch'd a hurricane of wind.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To eject or emit (something) with spasmodic force or noise.
examples: […] beneath him sound like waves on a desert shore
The voice of slaves beneath the sun, and children bought with money,
That shiver in religious caves beneath the burning fires
Of lust, that belch incessant from the summits of the earth.
